Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: 3-D Simulations of i-Process Nucleosynthesis in the Early Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
All of the elements other than hydrogen and helium are created inside of stars by "nucleosynthesis" processes. The origin of the material that makes planets - and people - is thus intimately tied to the detailed process that take place within stars. The PI and his collaborators will use novel computational techniques and the most powerful computing resources available to simulate conditions inside the earliest stars in the universe. These simulations will be used to evaluate a postulated, but unexplored, nucleosynthesis mechanism they call the "i-process". Graduate students will be trained in cutting-edge stellar modeling and computational astrophysics by one of the world leaders in this field. The potential for probing new forms of nucleosynthesis are of interest to the nuclear physics field as well as to astrophysics. Advanced techniques developed in this program could have applications in other areas of computational science.

The goal of this investigation is to simulate convection and nucleosynthesis processes inside the kind of stars that were present early in the universe. They will develop novel "autocorrecting" techniques to couple a 3-D treatment of convection with 1-D stellar evolution models, and they will generate a large database of results and tools to mine this database. These results will be accessible to the larger stellar modeling community, and they will chart new territory in computational astrophysics. These simulations should allow a probe of postulated nucleosynthesis processes that are driven by neutron capture at rates intermediate between the s- and r-processes.

This award is supported jointly by the Computational Physics Program in the Division of Physics and the Stellar Astronomy and Astrophysics Program in the Division of Astronomical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we have simulated processes deep inside stars of the early universe that involve hydrogen ingestion events caused by mixing of material across the boundaries of convection zones.  In 1-D stellar evolution simulations, these give rise to rapid hydrogen burning, with enormous energy release and causing nucleosynthesis by neutron capture from neutron fluxes intermediate between the slow (s) and rapid (r) processes.  This is the intermediate, or i-process nucleosynthesis that we targeted in this study.  Accurate treatment of the convective boundary mixing and the subsequent advection and nuclear burning of H in the He-burning convection zone that drives this i-process requires full 3-D simulation.  The rapid hydrogen burning that ensues, together with the very large luminosities involved, make 3-D simulation affordable on NSF's powerful supercomputing platforms, such as Blue Waters, at NCSA, and now Frontera, at TACC.

In this project, we took substantial steps to build a new and powerful capability to simulate these events by coupling together 3-D simulations that cover brief time intervals with 1-D simulations spanning much longer times.  In some cases, it is possible to simulate the entire event in 3-D.  In others, 3-D simulations performed at intervals as part of a coupled 1-D and 3-D stellar evolution calculation can serve to recalibrate the coefficients in approximate 1-D models for dynamic mixing processes.  Such coupled calculations can use these periodic model recalibrations to validate the use of the models as the calculation progresses.  We call this new process autocorrecting modeling.  It involves periodic generation of large amounts of 3-D data from simulation codes.  This data generation is followed by a detailed analysis of the data in terms of 1-D models.  The results of this analysis are then fed back into the 1-D stellar evolution computation.

Over the course of this project, we simulated multiple examples of hydrogen ingestion events in evolved stars.  In addition, we carried out a detailed and extensive study of the mixing of gases at the boundaries of stellar convection zones that drives these ingestion events.  We used those studies to validate 1-D models of the convective boundary mixing.  We also determined scaling laws that we can exploit to reduce the cost of the necessary 3-D stellar hydrodynamic simulations.  As we moved our attention over the course of this project to massive stars, we explored the possible impacts on the evolution of a massive star from interactions of convective shells driven by nuclear burning.  This work is continuing under a new NSF grant, and many of the techniques that we developed in the project are illustrated by the Figures, which show results from a recent simulation of a convective H/He shell interaction in a 45 Mʘ population-III star of the early universe.  The simulation was carried out with our PPMstar code on 7020 nodes of NSF's new Frontera machine at TACC, updating a grid of 38403 cells 16 times a second at over 4 Pflop/s sustained performance.

In the first figure, we show a volume rendering of the vorticity magnitude in the central portion of the star.  The continual injection of heat from helium burning at the base of the inner of this star's two convection zones is causing highly turbulent plumes of relatively buoyant gas to rise toward the top of the convection zone.  After reaching the top of the convection zone, they must spread out laterally, entraining a bit of the gas from above the convection zone and carrying it back downward with them when these laterally spreading plumes collide.  In Figs. 2 through 5, we see volume renderings of the magnitude of vorticity in a small section of a very thin slice through the center of the star.  The grid in this simulation is so fine that we can zoom in close to the thin layer of stably stratified gas separating the two convection zones to observe its interactions with the increasingly violent energy release from the burning of entrained gas.  In Fig. 2, at 832 min., the stably stratified layer is clearly traced by a thin line of very strong vorticity (hence shear) at its lower surface.  The layer is of constant thickness and is very nearly spherical.  In Fig. 3, at 1017 min., the convection has become more violent, and a small distortion of the stable layer is now evident.  In Fig. 4, at 1147 min., a wave of disturbed gas can be seen traveling around the stable layer and just above it, like a tsunami.  In Fig. 5, at 1213 min., the spherical focusing of wave energy associated with the hydrogen ingestion event forces the stable layer outward near the upper left in the image.  At this time, the presence of an impenetrable and immovable confining sphere that acts as our outer boundary condition for this simulation begins to strongly affect the flow.
